{{Redirect|Us and them||Us and Them (disambiguation){{!}}Us and Them}} In [[sociology]] and [[social psychology]], an '''ingroup''' is a [[social group]] to which a person [[self-categorization theory|psychologically identifies]] as being a member. By contrast, an '''outgroup''' is a social group with which an individual does not identify. For example, people may find it psychologically meaningful to view themselves according to their [[Race (classification of human beings)|race]], [[culture]], [[gender]], age, or [[religion]]. It has been found that the psychological membership of social groups and categories is associated with a wide variety of phenomena.
The terminology was made popular by [[Henri Tajfel]] and colleagues during his work in formulating [[social identity theory]]. The significance of ingroup and outgroup categorization was identified using a method called the [[minimal group paradigm]]. Tajfel and colleagues found that people can form self-preferencing ingroups within a matter of minutes and that such groups can form even on the basis of completely arbitrary and invented discriminatory characteristics, such as preferences for certain paintings.<ref>See "Kandinsky versus Klee experiment", [[Henri Tajfel|Tajfel]] ''[[et al.]]'' (1971) in [http://www.holah.karoo.net/tajfestudy.htm Tajfel, H. (1970). Experiments in Intergroup Discrimination].</ref><ref>{{cite journal |title=Experiments in intergroup discrimination |author=Tajfel, H. |journal=[[Scientific American]] |publisher=[[Springer Nature]] |volume=223 |pages=96–102 |date=1970 |jstor=24927662 |pmid=5482577}}</ref><ref>[http://www.box.net/shared/static/ieahzod96e.PDF Tajfel, H. (1970). Experiments in Intergroup Discrimination] = [http://www.lucs.lu.se/wp-content/uploads/2015/02/tajfel-experiments-in-intergroup-discrimination-1970.pdf Tajfel, H. (1970). Experiments in Intergroup Discrimination].</ref><ref>{{cite journal |author1=Tajfel, H. |author2=Billig, M. G. |author3=Bundy, R. P. |author4=Flament, C. |title=Social categorization and intergroup behaviour |journal=[[European Journal of Social Psychology]] |volume=1 |issue=2 |pages=149–178 |date=April–June 1971 |publisher= |doi=10.1002/ejsp.2420010202 }}</ref><ref>[http://ssi.sagepub.com/content/13/2/65.full.pdf Tajfel, H. (1974). Social Identity and Intergroup Behavior].</ref>
==Associated phenomena== The psychological categorization of people into ingroup and outgroup members is associated with a variety of phenomena. The following examples have all received a great deal of academic attention.
===In-group favoritism=== {{Main article|In-group favoritism}} This refers to the fact that under certain conditions, people will prefer and have affinity for one’s ingroup over the outgroup, or anyone viewed as outside the ingroup. This can be expressed in one's evaluation of others, linking, allocation of resources, and many other ways.<ref name=aronson>{{cite book |title=Social psychology |author=[[Elliot Aronson|Aronson, E.]], [[Timothy Wilson|Wilson, T. D.]], Akert, R. D. & Sommers, S. R.|year=2015|publisher=[[Pearson Education]] |location=London |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=nIVHrgEACAAJ| edition=9th, illustrated, revised|id={{ISBN|978-0-133-93654-4}} | isbn=0-13393654-6}}</ref>
===Outgroup derogation=== Discrimination between ingroups and outgroups is a matter of favoritism towards an ingroup and the absence of equivalent favoritism towards an outgroup.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Brewer|first=Marilynn B.|authorlink=Marilynn Brewer|title=The Psychology of Prejudice: Ingroup Love and Outgroup Hate?|journal=[[Journal of Social Issues]]|date=Fall 1999|volume=55|issue=3|pages=429–444|doi=10.1111/0022-4537.00126}}</ref> Outgroup derogation is the phenomenon in which an outgroup is perceived as being threatening to the members of an ingroup.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Hewstone|first1=Miles|authorlink1=Miles Hewstone |last2=Rubin|first2=Mark|last3=Willis|first3=Hazel|title=Intergroup Bias|date=February 2002|journal=[[Annual Review of Psychology]] | pages=575–604 |volume=53|doi=10.1146/annurev.psych.53.100901.135109|pmid=11752497}}</ref> This phenomenon often accompanies ingroup favoritism, as it requires one to have an affinity towards their ingroup. Some research suggests that outgroup derogation occurs when an outgroup is perceived as blocking or hindering the goals of an ingroup. It has also been argued that outgroup derogation is a natural consequence of the categorization process.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Zhong|first1=Chen-Bo|last2=Phillips|first2=Katherine W.|last3=Leonardelli|first3=Geoffrey J.|last4=Galinsky|first4=Adam D.|title=Negational categorization and intergroup behavior|journal=[[Personality and Social Psychology Bulletin]]|year=2008|volume=34|issue=6|pages=793–806|pmid=18391025|doi=10.1177/0146167208315457}}</ref>
===Social influence=== {{Main article|Social influence}} People have been shown to be differentially influenced by ingroup members. That is, under conditions where group categorization is psychologically salient, people will shift their beliefs in line with ingroup [[Norm (social)|social norms]].
===Group polarization=== {{Main article|Group polarization}} This generally refers to the tendency of groups to make decisions that are more extreme than the initial inclination of its members, although polarization toward the most central beliefs has also been observed. It has been shown that this effect is related to a psychologically salient ingroup and outgroup categorization.
===Group homogeneity=== {{Main article|Outgroup homogeneity}} Categorization of people into social groups increases the perception that group members are similar to one another. An outcome of this is the outgroup homogeneity effect. This refers to the perception of members of an outgroup as being homogenous, while members of one's ingroup are perceived as being diverse, e.g. "they are alike; we are diverse”.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Leyens|first1=Jacques-Philippe|last2=Yzerbyt|first2=Vincent|last3=Schadron|first3=Georges|title=Stereotypes and Social Cognition|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=_SO3AAAAIAAJ|year=1994|publisher=[[SAGE Publications]] |location=[[Thousand Oaks, California]] |isbn=0-80398583-5 |id={{ISBN|978-0-803-98583-4}}|pages=104–107}}</ref><ref name="Quattrone & Jones (1980)">{{cite journal|last1=Quattrone|first1=George A.|last2=Jones|first2=Edward E.|title=The perception of variability within in-groups and out-groups: Implications for the law of small numbers.|journal=[[Journal of Personality and Social Psychology]]|volume=38|issue=1|year=1980|pages=141–152|issn=0022-3514|doi=10.1037/0022-3514.38.1.141}}</ref> This is especially likely to occur in regard to negative characteristics. Under certain conditions, ingroup members can be perceived as being similar to one another in regard to positive characteristics. This effect is called ingroup homogeneity.<ref>{{cite book|last=Jackson|first=Lynne M.|title=The Psychology of Prejudice: From Attitudes to Social Action|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Q8MkAQAAMAAJ|year=2011|publisher=[[American Psychological Association]]|location=Washington, DC|isbn=1-43380920-6|id={{ISBN|978-1-433-80920-0}}|pages=110–112}}</ref>
==Postulated role in human evolution==
In [[evolutionary psychology]], ingroup favoritism is seen as an evolved mechanism selected for the advantages of [[coalition]] affiliation.<ref>{{cite journal |author1=L. Cosmides |author2=J. Tooby |author3=R. Kurzban |title=Perceptions of race |journal=Trends in Cognitive Sciences |volume=7 |issue=4 |pages=173–179 | date=April 1, 2003 |publisher= |doi=10.1016/S1364-6613(03)00057-3 |pmid= 12691766|pmc= |url=http://www.cell.com/trends/cognitive-sciences//retrieve/pii/S1364661303000573?cc=y |accessdate=16 July 2012}}</ref> It has been argued that characteristics such as gender and [[ethnicity]] are inflexible or even [[Essentialism|essential]] features of such systems.<ref>{{cite book |title=Race in the Making: Cognition, Culture, and the Child's Construction of Human Kinds |author=L. A. Hirschfeld |year=1996 |publisher=Mit Press |location=Cambridge, Massachusetts |url=https://books.google.Com/books?id=rXubQgAACAAJ | id={{ISBN|978-0-26208247-1}} | isbn=0-26208247-0}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |author=F. J. Gil-White |title=Are Ethnic Groups Biological "Species" to the Human Brain? Essentialism in Our Cognition of Some Social Categories |journal=[[Current Anthropology]] |volume=42 |issue=4 |pages=515–553 |date=August–October 2001 |publisher=[[University of Chicago Press]] |pmid= |pmc= |jstor=10.1086/321802 |doi=10.1086/321802}}</ref> However, there is evidence that elements of favoritism are flexible in that they can be erased by changes in social categorization.<ref>{{cite journal |author1=R. Kurzban |author2=J. Tooby |author3=L. Cosmides |title=Can race be erased? Coalitional computation and social categorization |journal=[[Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences of the United States of America]]|volume=98 |issue=26 |pages=15387–15392 |date=December 18, 2001 |publisher= |doi=10.1073/pnas.251541498 |pmid=11742078 |pmc=65039|bibcode=2001PNAS...9815387K }}</ref> One study in the field of [[behavioural genetics]] suggests that biological mechanisms may exist which favor a coexistence of both flexible and [[essentialist]] systems.<ref>{{cite journal |author1=G. J. Lewis |author2=T. C. Bates |title=Genetic Evidence for Multiple Biological Mechanisms Underlying In-Group Favoritism|journal=[[Psychological Science]] |volume=21 |issue=11 |pages=1623–1628 |date=November 2010 |publisher= |doi=10.1177/0956797610387439 |pmid=20974715 |pmc= |url=http://pss.sagepub.com/content/21/11/1623.short |accessdate=16 July 2012}}</ref>

{{Unencyclopædic tone|date=January 2013}} [[File:International Futures Logo.jpg|thumb|upright=1.7|right|International Futures (IFs) Logo]]
'''International Futures (IFs)''' is a global [[integrated assessment modelling|integrated assessment model]] designed to help in thinking strategically and systematically about key global systems (economic, demographic, education, health, environment, technology, domestic governance, infrastructure, agriculture, energy and environment) housed at the Frederick S. Pardee Center for International Futures. Initially created by [[Barry B. Hughes]] of the [[Josef Korbel School of International Studies]] at the [[University of Denver]] in [[Colorado]],<ref>Documentation can be found at http://www.ifs.du.edu regarding the history of IFs, specifically http://www.ifs.du.edu/ifs/IfsWebSite/IFs%20History.htm gives an overview of the different generations of IFs development. See this for a TEDx talk about the model: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=at47WLuA8Ks</ref> the model is free for public use in both its online and downloadable forms.<ref>Barry Hughes,and Evan Hillebrand Paradigm Publishing, 2006</ref>
The Pardee Center for International Futures has partnered with many organizations to produce forecasts and data analysis. IFs has been utilized in the [[National Intelligence Council|National Intelligence Council's]] ''Global Trends 2020'', ''Global Trends 2025'', and ''Global Trends 2030'' report.<ref>See [http://www.foia.cia.gov/2020/2020.pdf ''Mapping the Future: Report of the National Intelligence Council's 2020 Report''] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120916051336/http://www.foia.cia.gov/2020/2020.pdf |date=2012-09-16 }} and [http://www.aicpa.org/research/cpahorizons2025/globalforces/downloadabledocuments/globaltrends.pdf ''Global Trends 2025: A Transformed World''] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120813062044/http://www.aicpa.org/research/cpahorizons2025/globalforces/downloadabledocuments/globaltrends.pdf |date=2012-08-13 }} and [http://www.dni.gov/index.php/carousel-items/778-global-trends-2030-alternative-worlds-available-for-download ''Global Trends 2030: Alternative Worlds''] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121215110105/http://www.dni.gov/index.php/carousel-items/778-global-trends-2030-alternative-worlds-available-for-download |date=2012-12-15 }} [[Director of National Intelligence]]</ref> The International Futures model has also contributed to the United Nations ''[[Human Development Report]]''<ref>[http://hdr.undp.org/en/reports/global/hdr2011/papers/HDRP_2011_08.pdf ''Forecasting the Impacts of Environmental Constraints on Human Development'']</ref> and the ''[[Global Environment Outlook|Global Environmental Outlook]]''.
IFs is hosted free for public use by [[Google Public Data Explorer]], the [[Atlantic Council]], and the [[Institute for Security Studies]].<ref>For hosts of the web-based version of the model, see International Futures on [http://www.google.com/publicdata/explore?ds=n4ff2muj8bh2a_ Google Public Data Explorer], The Atlantic Council and the [http://www.acus.org/program/strategic-foresight-initiative Strategic Foresight Initiative] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121115045307/http://www.acus.org/program/strategic-foresight-initiative |date=2012-11-15 }}, and the Institute for Security Studies, as a part of the [http://www.issafrica.org/futures African Futures Project]. Additionally, the web version of the model is found on the [http://www.ifs.du.edu/ifs/Ifs.aspx International Futures] website.</ref>
== Model structure == The model incorporates dynamically linked sub-models. They include: population, economic, agricultural, educational, energy, socio-political, international political, environmental, health, infrastructure and technology.<ref>[http://www.ifs.du.edu/introduction/elements.aspx Elements of International Futures], a structural explanation of the IFs model with block diagram.</ref> IFs is a unique modeling tool because it endogenizes the impact of such a wide range of global systems for 183 countries.
The help system that accompanies the software<ref>[http://www.ifs.du.edu/ifs Index<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> provides an extensive overview of the model structure and computer code used to write the model. IFs has three main functions, all connected to its conceptual treatment of integrated assessment forecasts: data analysis, scenario analysis, and display.<ref>An extended introductory video is found here: http://vimeo.com/11090851</ref>
== Data analysis == [[File:Crosssect.jpg|thumb|right|Example of cross-sectional analysis of [[total fertility rate]] and [[GDP]] per capita at [[purchasing power parity]]]] The data analysis section of IFs represents a collection of over 2,000 data series from all major international data gatherers. It is constantly updated with new data series. This data forms the foundation of the model structure. Users can analyze historic data cross-sectionally, longitudinally or on a [[world map]]. Using [[cross-sectional analysis]], users can select a [[Variable (mathematics)|variables]] and plot this against up to 5 [[independent variables]]. It is then possible to animate the map to see how the cross-sectional relationship changes across the 40+ years of data in the [[database]]. Longitudinally, users can plot the relationship between a [[dependent variable]] and time, from 1960 (for most data series) through the most recent data year available. A world map allows users to display data from any of these series using [[GIS]] options.
== Scenario analysis == [[File:IFsWorldPopulationHistoryForecastII.jpg|thumb|right| Forecast of world population for four [[UNEP]] scenarios from 1960–2100]]
The software allows users to access and change the [[parameters]] and [[Variable (mathematics)|variables]] that are used in the model. The [[scenario analysis|Scenario Analysis]] display lets users create their own global scenario or load a pre-run global scenario in their field of interest. For example, to analyze the effects of a policy intervention on different sub-models and variables within the model, make the changes to the appropriate variable and then analyze the results in comparison to the base-case. Many pre-run scenarios come packaged with the model, including work that has been completed for the [[United Nations Environment Programme]]<ref>See the [http://www.unep.org/geo/GEO4/report/GEO-4_Report_Full_en.pdf ''Global Environmental Outlook 4''] {{webarchive|url=http://arquivo.pt/wayback/20090707225845/http://www.unep.org/geo/geo4/report/GEO-4_Report_Full_en.pdf |date=2009-07-07 }} that IFs made a contribution to</ref> and the [[National Intelligence Council]].<ref>[http://www.foia.cia.gov/2020/2020.pdf ''Mapping the Future: Report of the National Intelligence Council's 2020 Report''] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120916051336/http://www.foia.cia.gov/2020/2020.pdf |date=2012-09-16 }} and [http://www.aicpa.org/research/cpahorizons2025/globalforces/downloadabledocuments/globaltrends.pdf ''Global Trends 2025: A Transformed World''] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120813062044/http://www.aicpa.org/research/cpahorizons2025/globalforces/downloadabledocuments/globaltrends.pdf |date=2012-08-13 }}</ref>
== Display == [[File:Mortalitydisplay.jpg|thumb|right|Example of mortality display for Belgium in 2025]] This portion of the software allows users to display the forecast results of their scenario analyses for different provinces, countries and groups across different issue areas. Some of the specialized displays include: population, educational attainment, mortality rate, [[World Values Survey]], [[Gini coefficient]], the [[Millennium Development Goals]], [[social accounting matrix]], advanced sustainability analysis, and [[World Bank]] financial flows.
== Pardee Center for International Futures ==
The project received a gift from [[Frederick S. Pardee]], formerly of [[RAND]], to construct the '''Pardee Center for International Futures''' at the [[University of Denver]].<ref>at {{cite web |url=http://www.ifs.du.edu/pardee/index.aspx |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2012-09-04 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120902033255/http://www.ifs.du.edu/pardee/index.aspx |archivedate=2012-09-02 |df= }}</ref> It is responsible for the further institutionalization of the software, training sessions, and the continued work on the ''Patterns of Potential Human Progress'' (PPHP) volumes. The first PPHP volume discusses reduction in global poverty; the second, global education; the third, health care systems; the fourth, global infrastructure; the fifth, domestic governance.<ref>These can be downloaded either in final or draft form on their website "http://www.ifs.du.edu/documents/index.aspx"</ref>
The journal [[Poverty and Public Policy]] reviewed the first PPHP volume, and concluded the following:
:For all their fine effort in data assembly and analysis, Hughes et al. intended that their first volume’s main contribution should be one not of prediction, but of promoting thought about poverty policy. Their attractively presented and lucid volume succeeds in this endeavor; it very usefully fulfills its promise to the student and policymaker.<ref>Soltys, Dennis (2010) “Review of Reducing Global Poverty: Patterns of Potential Human Progress, Vol. 1," Poverty & Public Policy: Vol. 2: Iss. 2, Article 10.</ref>
== African Futures Project ==
The African Futures Project is a collaboration between the [[Institute for Security Studies]] and the Pardee Center for International Futures to promote long term strategic planning for African development. This collaboration has led to the publication of various African Futures Project Policy Briefs,<ref>See the [http://www.issafrica.org/futures/publications.php Publications Section] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131006215455/http://www.issafrica.org/futures/publications.php |date=2013-10-06 }} of the African Futures website for introductory videos and to read the policy briefs in full.</ref> monographs on long-term African Development and a website where the IFs model can be used specifically for exploring African development.<ref>See the African Futures Project at: {{cite web |url=http://www.iss.co.za/futures/ |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2012-09-04 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130403153619/http://www.iss.co.za/futures/ |archivedate=2013-04-03 |df= }}</ref>

{{refimprove|date=December 2016}} '''Iron''', when used [[metaphor]]ically, refers to certain traits of the [[metal]] [[iron]]. Used as an [[adjective]] and sometimes as a [[noun]], it refers to something stern, harsh, unyielding, inflexible, rigid, sturdy, strong, robust, hard.<ref>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/special_report/1999/02/99/e-cyclopedia/506459.stm "Iron: The man in the mask"], ''[[BBC News]]'' article from 1999</ref><ref>[https://www.ahdictionary.com/word/search.html?q=iron Iron], definition at ''[[The American Heritage Dictionary]] of Idioms''</ref><ref>''[[Random House Webster's Unabridged Dictionary]]''{{Nonspecific|date=January 2017}}</ref>
{{toc right}} ==List of iron metaphors==

===Animals and plants=== * [[Iron Bird (disambiguation)]] * [[Iron Butterfly (disambiguation)]] * [[Iron Dragon (disambiguation)]] * [[Iron Eagle (disambiguation)]] * [[Iron Monkey (disambiguation)]] * [[Iron Wolf (disambiguation)]] * [[Iron horse (disambiguation)]] * [[Iron wood (disambiguation)]] * ''Ferrocalamus'' ([[iron bamboo]]) * [[Iron cobra]], a "construct" in the game ''Dungeons & Dragons'' * [[Iron condor]], an option trading strategy utilizing two vertical spreads * Iron Kong, a fictional character from the science fiction media franchise [[Zoids]]

{{Other uses|Law of attraction (disambiguation){{!}}Law of attraction}} {{New Thought beliefs}}
In the [[New Thought]] philosophy, the '''Law of Attraction''' is the belief that by focusing on positive or negative thoughts, people can bring positive or negative experiences into their life.<ref name=gazette>Whittaker, S. [http://www.canada.com/montrealgazette/story.html?id=78fc94dd-c0b2-4ade-891d-98770bfae388&k=70777 Secret attraction] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304090328/http://www.canada.com/montrealgazette/story.html?id=78fc94dd-c0b2-4ade-891d-98770bfae388&k=70777 |date=2016-03-04 }}, ''The Montreal Gazette'', May 12, 2007.</ref><ref>Redden, Guy, "Magic Happens: A New Age Metaphysical Mystery Tour", ''Journal of Australian Studies'': 101</ref> The belief is based on the idea that people and their thoughts are both made from pure energy, and that through the process of like energy attracting like energy a person can improve their own health, wealth, and personal relationships.
The [https://realpsychicnow.biz/ways-to-attract-abundance-and-prosperity-in-your-life/ Law of Attraction] is among the most popular of the Universal Laws.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Ellison|first1=A|title=Metaphysics and Universal Laws|url=http://mysticculture.com/metaphysics-and-universal-laws/|website=Mystic Culture|publisher=Mystic Culture|accessdate=20 February 2018}}</ref> Advocates of this mind-power paradigm generally combine [[Cognitive reframing|cognitive reframing techniques]] with affirmations and [[creative visualization]] to replace limiting or self-destructive ("negative") thoughts with more empowered, adaptive ("positive") thoughts. A key component of the philosophy is that in order to effectively change one's negative thinking patterns, one must also "feel" (through creative visualization) that the desired changes have already occurred. This combination of positive thought and positive emotion is believed to allow one to attract positive experiences and opportunities by achieving resonance with the proposed energetic law.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thelawofattraction.com/what-is-the-law-of-attraction/|title=What Is The Law Of Attraction|last1=Hurst|first1=Katherine|date=|website=The Law Of Attraction|accessdate=}}</ref>
The Law of Attraction has no scientific basis<ref name="Scientific American">{{cite web | last = Shermer | first = Michael | authorlink = Michael Shermer | title = The (Other) Secret | work = [[Scientific American]] | date = 1 June 2007 | url = https://www.scientificamerican.com/article/the-other-secret/ | accessdate = 31 March 2017 }}</ref> and has been dubbed a [[pseudoscience]].<ref name="Live Science">{{cite web | last = Radford | first = Benjamin | authorlink = Benjamin Radford | title = The Pseudoscience of 'The Secret' | work = [[Live Science]] | date = 3 February 2009 | url = http://www.livescience.com/5303-pseudoscience-secret.html | accessdate = 31 March 2017 }}</ref> A number of researchers have criticized the misuse of scientific concepts by its proponents.<ref name="Scientific American"/><ref>{{cite web|last=Stenger |first=Victor J. |title=Cosmic Mind |url=http://www.colorado.edu/philosophy/vstenger/Quantum/01CosmicMind.pdf |publisher=University of Colorado |authorlink=Victor_Stenger |pages=8–19 |format=PDF |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150924013317/http://www.colorado.edu/philosophy/vstenger/Quantum/01CosmicMind.pdf |archivedate=2015-09-24 |df= }}</ref><ref name="Leon Lederman 1993 189–198">{{cite book |title=The God Particle: If the Universe is the Answer, What is the Question |pages=189–198 |author=Leon Lederman |author2=Dick Teresi |date=1993 |publisher=Houghton Mifflin Company}}</ref><ref name="plato.stanford.edu">[http://plato.stanford.edu/entries/pseudo-science/#NonSciPosSci Non-science posing as science; Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy]</ref>
==History== The [[New Thought]] movement (Law of Attraction Origins) grew out of the teachings of [[Phineas Quimby]] in the early 19th century. Early in his life, Quimby was diagnosed with tuberculosis. However, medicinal treatment wasn't working, so he began carriage riding through his hometown, Lebanon, New Hampshire. He then regained his health and recovered, an event that prompted his study of "mind over body".<ref>{{cite web|last1=Hughes|first1=n|title=Phineas Parkhurst Quimby|url=http://phineasquimby.wwwhubs.com/|accessdate=5 December 2017}}</ref> Although he never used the words 'Law of Attraction', he explained this in a statement that captured the concept in the field of health: {{quote|the trouble is in the mind, for the body is only the house for the mind to dwell in, and we put a value on it according to its worth. Therefore if your mind has been deceived by some invisible enemy into a belief, you have put it into the form of a disease, with or without your knowledge. By my theory or truth, I come in contact with your enemy and restore you to your health and happiness. This I do partly mentally and partly by talking till I correct the wrong impressions and establish the Truth, and the Truth is the cure.<ref>{{cite web|title=The Quimby Manuscripts|url=http://newthoughtlibrary.com/quimbyPhineas/manuscripts/pages/quimby-manuscripts-194.htm|publisher=New Thought library|accessdate=1 June 2015}}</ref>|sign=|source=}}
In 1877, the term 'Law of Attraction' appeared in print for the first time in a book written by the Russian occultist [[Helena Blavatsky]], in a context alluding to an attractive power existing between elements of spirit.<ref>{{cite web|title=Isis Unveiled|url=http://www.theosociety.org/pasadena/isis/iu1-10.htm|publisher=Theosophical University Press, page 340|accessdate=2 July 2015}}</ref> (Her book ''Isis Unveiled'' discusses esoteric mysteries of ancient theosophy.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Blavatsky|first1=Helena|title=Isis Unveiled|url=http://www.theosociety.org/pasadena/isis/iu-hp.htm}}</ref>)
But the one who really first articulated the Law as general principle was [[Prentice Mulford]]. Mulford, a pivotal figure in the development of New Thought thinking, discusses the Law of Attraction at length in, for example, his essay "The Law of Success",<ref>{{cite web|title=Your Forces and How to Use Them, Vol. 1|url=https://archive.org/stream/yourforcesandho09mulfgoog#page/n66/mode/2up}}</ref> published 1886-1887. In this, Mulford was followed by other New Thought authors, such as Henry Wood (starting with his ''God’s Image in Man'',<ref>{{cite web|title=God's Image in Man, Ch. 6, "The Universality of Law"|url=https://archive.org/stream/godsimageinmans01woodgoog#page/n134/mode/2up}}</ref> 1892), and [[Ralph Waldo Trine]] (starting with his first book, ''What All the World's A-Seeking'',<ref>{{cite web|title=What All the World's A-Seeking|url=https://archive.org/details/whatallworldsas00tringoog}}</ref> 1896). For these authors, the Law of Attraction is concerned not only about health but every aspect of life.<ref>{{cite web|title=In Tune With The Infinite|url=http://newthoughtlibrary.com/trineRalphWaldo/inTune/pages/in-tune-with-the-infinite-026.htm#TopOfText|publisher=New Thought Library|accessdate=13 June 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=THE GOD IN YOU|url=http://prenticemulford.wwwhubs.com/tgiy.htm|publisher=Cornerstone Publishing, 2001|accessdate=2 July 2015}}</ref>
The 20th century saw a surge in interest in the subject with many books being written about it, amongst which are two of the [[List of best-selling books|best-selling books]] of all time; [[Think and Grow Rich]] (1937) by [[Napoleon Hill]] and [[You Can Heal Your Life]] (1984) by [[Louise Hay]].
Even if the [[New Age|New Age movement]] adopted many New Thought ideas, including that of the Law of Attraction, the Law of Attraction remains a new thought philosophical concept.<ref>{{cite web|title=A Company Aims to Put Good Karma and Energy Close at Hand|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2014/03/29/us/seeking-good-karma-a-company-aims-to-put-it-close-at-hand.html?_r=0|publisher=The New York Times, 28 March 2014|accessdate=2 July 2015}}</ref>
In 2006, the concept of the Law of Attraction gained a lot of renewed exposure with the release of the film ''[[The Secret (2006 film)|The Secret]]'' (2006) which was then developed into a book of the same title in 2007. The movie and book gained widespread media coverage.<ref name=gazette /><ref name=oprah1>{{cite web |url= http://www.oprah.com/spirit/The-Law-of-Attraction-Real-Life-Stories_1 |title=The Law of Attraction: Real-Life Stories - Oprah.com |work=oprah.com |accessdate=November 8, 2010}}</ref><ref name=oprah2>{{cite web |url= http://www.oprah.com/spirit/Go-Beyond-The-Secret_1 |title=Go Beyond 'The Secret' - Oprah.com |work=oprah.com |accessdate=November 8, 2010}}</ref> [[Rhonda Byrne]]'s book also has influenced the creation of an untitled fiction film based on The Secret, starring Katie Holmes.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.thelawofattraction.com/the-secret-movie/|title=The Secret Movie (2018) Based on The Secret by Rhonda Byrne|date=2017-09-08|work=The Law Of Attraction|access-date=2017-09-18|language=en-US}}</ref> This was followed by a sequel, [[The Power (self-help book)|The Power]] in 2010 that talks about the law of attraction being the law of love.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://abcnews.go.com/Business/power-author-rhonda-byrnes-book/story?id=11421349|title=The Secret Is Out: Megahit Writer Says Power of Love Will Fill Your Bank Account|last=NANCE-NASH|first=SHERYL|date=August 18, 2010|work=ABC News|access-date=August 29, 2018}}</ref>
==Descriptions== New Thought authors believe that the Law of Attraction is always in operation and that it brings to each person the conditions and experiences that they predominantly think about, or which they desire or expect.
[[Charles F. Haanel|Charles Haanel]] wrote in ''[[The Master Key System]]'' (1912): {{quote|The law of attraction will certainly and unerringly bring to you the conditions, environment, and experiences in life, corresponding with your habitual, characteristic, predominant mental attitude.<ref>{{cite web|title=The Master Key System. Chapter 8, part 18.|url=http://newthoughtlibrary.com/haanel-charles/Master-Key-System/audioEbook/master-key-systemRAW.pdf|publisher=New Thought Library|accessdate=25 June 2015}}</ref>|sign=|source=}}
Ralph Trine wrote in ''In Tune With The Infinite'' (1897): {{quote|The law of attraction works universally on every plane of action, and we attract whatever we desire or expect. If we desire one thing and expect another, we become like houses divided against themselves, which are quickly brought to desolation. Determine resolutely to expect only what you desire, then you will attract only what you wish for.<ref>{{cite web|title=In Tune With The Infinite, by Ralph Trine|url=http://newthoughtlibrary.com/trineRalphWaldo/inTune/pages/in-tune-with-the-infinite-035.htm#TopOfText|publisher=New Thought Library|accessdate=18 June 2015}}</ref>}} Rhonda Byrne published in 2006 the film [[The Secret (2006 film)|The Secret]] wherein she emphasized thinking about what each person wants to obtain, but also to infuse the thought with the maximum possible amount of emotion. She claims the combination of thought and feeling is what attracts the desire.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.tameyourmind.org/articles/how-can-it-possibly-be-law-attraction-works|title=How can it possibly be that the law of attraction works?|last=Henry|first=Juliette|date=|website=www.tameyourmind.org|publisher=Transformation guide|access-date=3 Dec 2016}}</ref> The Secret says your subconscious mind can control everything that happens around you, including both positive experiences, like having someone call you from miles away, and negative experiences, like death. The Byrne underlines the power of the subconscious mind by asking the reader to take full control of these thoughts, in order to achieve things in life, with the mind, as much as with action. Another similar book is [[James Redfield]]'s ''[[The Celestine Prophecy]]'', which says reality can be manifested by man.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Redfield|first1=James|title=The Celestine Prophecy: An Adventure|date=1993|publisher=Warner Books|location=New York}}</ref> Man and the universe have a force of attraction between them similar to a magnetic attraction. ''The Power of Your Subconscious Mind'' by Joseph Murphy, says readers can achieve seemingly impossible goals by learning how to bring the mind itself under control. ''The Power'' by Rhonda Byrne, ''The Alchemist'' by Paulo Coelho, and ''The Power of Now'' by Eckhart Tolle are similar. While personal testimonies claim the secret and the law to have worked for them, a number of skeptics have criticized Rhonda Byrne's film and book. ''[[The New York Times Book Review]]'' called the secret pseudoscience and an "illusion of knowledge".<ref>{{cite news|last1=Chabris|first1=Christopher F.|last2=Simons|first2=Daniel J.|title=The Pseudoscience of ‘The Secret’ and ‘The Power’|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2010/09/26/books/review/Chabris-t.html|accessdate=2017-08-13|work=The New York Times|date=24 September 2010}}</ref>
==Philosophical and religious basis== The New Thought concept of the Law of Attraction is rooted in ideas that come from various philosophical and religious traditions. In particular, it has been inspired by [[Hermeticism]], [[New England transcendentalism]], specific verses from the [[Bible]], and [[Hinduism]], <ref>{{cite web|last1=Melanson|first1=Terry|title=Oprah Winfrey, New Thought, "The Secret" and the "New Alchemy" |url=http://www.conspiracyarchive.com/2014/07/20/oprah-winfrey-new-thought-the-secret-and-the-new-alchemy/|publisher=Conspiracy Archive|accessdate=27 November 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|last1=D'Aoust|first1=Maja|title=The Secret Source|date=2012|publisher=Process|isbn=978-1-934170-32-8|page=19}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|last1=Zink|first1=Robert|title=Magical Energy Healing: The Ruach Healing Method|date=2014|publisher=Law of Attraction Solutions, Llc|isbn=978-0990825036|page=299|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=6kJ8BwAAQBAJ&pg=PA299&lpg=PA299&dq=%22law+of+attraction%22+%22emerald+tablet%22&source=bl&ots=HeQ-lgA9fH&sig=SdM_Ptlcj9nRkuGktQ9PUU0deLw&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwiMn_rk8J_JAhXHcBoKHQPqDh04ChDoAQg1MAQ#v=onepage&q=%22law%20of%20attraction%22%20%22emerald%20tablet%22&f=false|accessdate=20 November 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|last1=Donker|first1=Gerald|title=Exposing the Secret Law of Attraction|date=2008|publisher=Lulu.com|isbn=978-1409236146|page=27|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=sCsqAgAAQBAJ&pg=PA27&lpg=PA27&dq=%22the+new+thought%22+%22law+of+attraction%22+bible&source=bl&ots=I2nHuXjvuo&sig=0opyxIpXucuBoCSVs8hn1ZjrM4k&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0CEwQ6AEwCWoVChMIstObivH5yAIVA48-Ch2yYgXc#v=onepage&q=%22the%20new%20thought%22%20%22law%20of%20attraction%22%20bible&f=false|accessdate=6 November 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|last1=Harrold|first1=Glenn|title=The Answer: Supercharge the Law of Attraction and Find the Secret of True Happiness|date=2011|publisher=Orion|isbn=978-1409112716|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=N917eoI9LzcC&pg=PT50&lpg=PT50&dq=%22law+of+attraction%22+hinduism+%22new+thought%22&source=bl&ots=_XdcKbNOdL&sig=EWlqS-Q9kGGm0EHLZrxLhJmjU4M&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwij87m2gLHJAhWCXBQKHQu0B28Q6AEISDAH#v=onepage&q=%22law%20of%20attraction%22%20hinduism%20%22new%20thought%22&f=false|accessdate=27 November 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|last1=James|first1=William|title=The Varieties of Religious Experience|date=1902|publisher=Longmans Green & Co|isbn=978-1439297278|page=94|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=UPLBAgAAQBAJ&pg=PA94&lpg=PA94&dq=william+James+%22mind-cure+is+the%22&source=bl&ots=0evSP6aFB6&sig=re-0rF_VQkCzzLR2ayhSV_3WgP4&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0CDcQ6AEwBWoVChMIy-SVvO75yAIVRGg-Ch36owbD#v=onepage&q=william%20James%20%22mind-cure%20is%20the%22&f=false|accessdate=12 November 2015}}</ref>
Hermeticism influenced the development of European thought in the [[Renaissance]]. Its ideas were transmitted partly through [[alchemy]]. In the 18th century, [[Franz Mesmer]] studied the works of alchemists such as [[Paracelsus]]<ref>{{cite book|last1=D'Aoust|first1=Maja|title=The Secret Source|date=2012|publisher=Process|isbn=978-1-934170-32-8|page=16}}</ref> and [[Jan Baptist van Helmont|van Helmont]].<ref name=Hist/> Van Helmont was a 17th-century [[Flemish people|Flemish]] physician who proclaimed the curative powers of the imagination.<ref name=Hist/><ref>{{cite journal|last1=Hedesan|first1=Georgiana D.|title=Paracelsian Medicine and Theory of Generation in ‘Exterior homo’, a Manuscript Probably Authored by Jan Baptist Van Helmont (1579–1644), ref 52|journal=Medical History|date=July 2014|volume=58|issue=03|pmc=4103403|pmid=25045180|doi=10.1017/mdh.2014.29|pages=375–96}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last1=Hedesan|first1=Delia Georgiana|title=‘Christian Philosophy’: Medical Alchemy and Christian Thought in the Work of Jan Baptista Van Helmont (1579-1644)|date=2012|page= 31|url=https://ore.exeter.ac.uk/repository/bitstream/handle/10036/4083/HedesanD.pdf?sequence=4|accessdate=19 November 2015}}</ref> This lead Mesmer to develop his ideas about [[Animal magnetism]] which [[Phineas Quimby]], the founder of New Thought, studied.<ref name=Hist>{{cite web|last1=Braden|first1=Charles S.|title=A BRIEF HISTORY OF THE NEW THOUGHT MOVEMENT.(1963)|url=http://www.surrenderworks.com/library/downloads/braden.pdf|publisher=surrenderworks.com|accessdate=13 November 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=PHINEAS PARKHURST QUIMBY 1802 - 1866 Father of New Thought|url=http://phineasquimby.wwwhubs.com/|publisher=phineasquimby|accessdate=20 November 2015}}</ref>
The Transcendentalist movement developed in the United States immediately before the emergence of New Thought and is thought to have had a great influence on it. [[George Ripley (transcendentalist)|George Ripley]], an important figure in that movement, stated that its leading idea was "the supremacy of mind over matter".<ref name=Hist/><ref>{{cite book|last1=Mikics|first1=David|title=The Annotated Emerson|date=2012|publisher=Belknap Press|isbn=978-0674049239|page=6|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=nI3uBQAAQBAJ&pg=PA6&lpg=PA6&dq=%22george+ripley%22+%22the+supremacy+of+mind+over+matter%22&source=bl&ots=F4dN_3p4mO&sig=kr_BiWEHcVDvCHTbSaxHUW6apJI&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0CCYQ6AEwAWoVChMInfvbtLacyQIVim8UCh0YTg1T#v=onepage&q=%22george%20ripley%22%20%22the%20supremacy%20of%20mind%20over%20matter%22&f=false|accessdate=19 November 2015}}</ref>
New Thought authors often quote certain verses from the Bible in the context of the Law of Attraction. An example is [[Mark 11]]:24: "Therefore I tell you, whatever you ask in prayer, believe that you have received it, and it will be yours."<ref>{{cite web|title=Mark 11:24|url=https://www.biblegateway.com/passage/?search=mark+11%3A24&version=RSV|publisher=Bible Gateway|accessdate=5 November 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=The Master Key System, by Charles Haanel (1912). Chapter 11, section 17|url=http://newthoughtlibrary.com/haanel-charles/Master-Key-System/audioEbook/master-key-systemRAW.pdf|publisher=The New Thought Library|accessdate=5 November 2015}}</ref><ref name=secr>{{cite book|last1=Byrne|first1=Rhonda|title=The Secret|date=2006|publisher=Beyond Words|isbn=978-1-58270-170-7|page=54}}</ref>
In the late 19th century [[Swami Vivekananda]] traveled to the United States and gave lectures on [[Hinduism]]. These talks greatly influenced the New Thought movement and in particular, [[William Walker Atkinson]] who was one of New Thought's pioneers.<ref>{{cite book|last1=D'Aoust|first1=Maja|title=The Secret Source|date=2012|publisher=Process|isbn=978-1-934170-32-8|page=61}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|last1=Woodroffe|first1=John|title=Shakti and Shâkta, Chapter 24, 12th paragraph|date=1918|publisher=Luzac & Co|isbn=978-1595479204|url=http://www.sacred-texts.com/tantra/sas/sas24.htm| accessdate=13 February 2016}}</ref>
==Criticism== ''[[Skeptical Inquirer]]'' magazine criticized the lack of [[falsifiability]] and [[testability]] of these claims.<ref name="csicop.org">{{cite web|author1=Mary Carmichael |author2=Ben Radford |url=http://www.csicop.org/specialarticles/show/secrets_and_lies/ |title=CSI | Secrets and Lies |publisher=Csicop.org |date= |accessdate=2012-05-16}}</ref> Critics have asserted that the evidence provided is usually [[anecdotal]] and that, because of the [[publication bias|self-selecting nature of the positive reports]], as well as the [[Subjectivity|subjective]] nature of any results, these reports are susceptible to [[confirmation bias]] and [[selection bias]].<ref name="Kaptchuck">{{cite journal |author=Kaptchuk, T., & Eisenberg, D. |year=1998 |title=The Persuasive Appeal of Alternative Medicine |journal=Annals of Internal Medicine |volume=129 |issue=12 |pmid=9867762 |pages=1061–5 |doi=10.7326/0003-4819-129-12-199812150-00011|last2=Eisenberg }}</ref> Physicist [[Ali Alousi]], for instance, criticized it as unmeasurable and questioned the likelihood that thoughts can affect anything outside the head.<ref name=gazette/>
The Law of Attraction has been popularized in the early 21st century by books and films such as ''[[The Secret (book)|The Secret]]''. This 2006 film and the subsequent book<ref>{{cite book |title=The Secret |year=2006 |first=Rhonda |last=Byrne |publisher=Beyond Words Publishing |isbn=978-1-58270-170-7}}</ref> use interviews with New Thought authors and speakers to explain the principles of the proposed metaphysical law that one can attract anything that one thinks about consistently. Writing for the Committee for Skeptical Inquiry, [[Mary Carmichael]] and [[Ben Radford]] wrote that "neither the film nor the book has any basis in scientific reality", and that its premise contains "an ugly flipside: if you have an accident or disease, it's your fault".<ref name="csicop.org"/>
Others have questioned the references to modern scientific theory, and have maintained, for example, that the Law of Attraction misrepresents the electrical activity of [[Neural oscillation|brainwaves]].<ref>{{cite journal |journal=Scientific American |date=June 2007 |volume=296 |issue=6 |pages=39–39 |title=The (Other) Secret |url=http://www.sciam.com/article.cfm?id=the-other-secret |doi=10.1038/scientificamerican0607-39|last1=Shermer |first1=Michael }}</ref> [[Victor Stenger]] and [[Leon Lederman]] are critical of attempts to use [[quantum mysticism]] to bridge any unexplained or seemingly implausible effects, believing these to be traits of modern [[pseudoscience]].<ref>{{cite web|last=Stenger |first=Victor J. |title=Cosmic Mind |url=http://www.colorado.edu/philosophy/vstenger/Quantum/01CosmicMind.pdf |publisher=University of Colorado |authorlink=Victor_Stenger |pages=8–19 |format=PDF |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150924013317/http://www.colorado.edu/philosophy/vstenger/Quantum/01CosmicMind.pdf |archivedate=2015-09-24 |df= }}</ref><ref name="Leon Lederman 1993 189–198"/><ref name="plato.stanford.edu"/>
==Prominent supporters==
* In 1891 Californian author and humorist [[Prentice Mulford]] used the term Law of Attraction in his essays ''Some Laws of Health and Beauty'' and ''Good And Ill Effects of Thought''. * In 1897 [[Ralph Waldo Trine]] wrote ''In Tune with the Infinite''. In the second paragraph of chapter 9 he writes, "The Law of Attraction works unceasingly throughout the universe, and the one great and never changing fact in connection with it is, as we have found, that like attracts like."<ref>{{cite book|last1=Trine|first1=Ralph|title=In Tune With The Infinite|publisher=G Bell and Sons, LTD. Published 1911|location=London|page=174}}</ref> * [[Thomas Troward]], a strong influence in the New Thought Movement, gave a 1904 lecture in which he claimed that thought precedes physical form and "the action of Mind plants that nucleus which, if allowed to grow undisturbed, will eventually attract to itself all the conditions necessary for its manifestation in outward visible form."<ref>Judge Thomas Troward, ''The Edinburgh Lectures on Mental Science'', 1904.</ref> * In 1902 English New Thought writer [[James Allen (author)|James Allen]] (best known for writing ''[[As a Man Thinketh]]'') wrote a series of books and articles between 1901 and 1912, after which his wife [[Lily L. Allen|Lily]] continued his work. * [[Emmet Fox]] wrote about metaphysics and the power of prayer in essays and books. His teachings are founded in Christianity and bible stories.
